facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 386 of 1961 filed by special leave from the order dated August 3, 1959, of the Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur, in case No. 24/XII of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 386 of 1961. Appeal by Special leave from the order dated August 3, 1959, of the Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur, in case No. 24/XII of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on November 8, 1962 by SARKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. November 8. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.

facts.text: Appellant carried on both life and other kinds of insurance business as a composite insurer under the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant used to carry on both life and other kinds of insurance business It was what is called in the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956 a companyposite insurer.

facts.text: Life Insurance Corporation created by the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956 on September 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Corporation was created by this Act on September 1, 1956.and under s. 7 of the Act the terms of which we will have to set out later, all rights appertaining to the life insurance business of an insurer,

facts.text: Under section 7 of the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956, all rights appertaining to the life insurance business vested in the respondent Corporation on September 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: and under s. 7 of the Act the terms of which we will have to set out later, all rights appertaining to the life insurance business of an insurer, which in the Act is called the companytrolled business, because vested in the respondent Corporation on the appointed day, that is, September 1, 1956.

facts.text: Appellant entitled to certain refunds under Income-tax Act, 1922 for assessment years 1955-56 and 1956-57.

anchor.surface_text: Under the orders of assessment to income-tax for the years 1955-56 and 1956-57, the appellant became entitled to certain refunds under the provisions of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Respondent Corporation claimed part of the refunds under section 7 of the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956, resisted by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Corporation claimed a part of those refunds under s. 7 and this claim was resisted by the appellant.

facts.text: Life Insurance Tribunal decided the dispute in favor of the respondent Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: This dispute was taken to the Life Insurance Tribunal for decision under the Act of 1956 and this Tribunal decided it- in favour of the respondent Corporation.

facts.text: Present appeal is against the judgment of the Life Insurance Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is against the judgment of the Tribunal.

facts.text: Previous years for assessment years 1955-56 and 1956-57 were calendar years 1954 and 1955 respectively.

anchor.surface_text: The previous years of the appellant for the assessment years 1950-56 and 1956-57 were respectively the calendar years 1954 and 1955.

facts.text: In assessment year 1955-56, credit given to appellant: Rs. 48,271.56 for life department and Rs. 3,245.25 for general department.

anchor.surface_text: showed that in the first assessment year credit had been given to the appellant in the sum of Rs. 48,271.56 on account of taxes earlier paid in respect of its life department I and in the sum of Rs. 3,245.25 on the same account in respect of its general department.

facts.text: In assessment year 1956-57, credit given: Rs. 48,271.56 life, Rs. 3,196.25 general.

anchor.surface_text: The figures of taxes earlier paid for which credit had been given in its assessment for the second assessment year were, Rs 48,271 56 in respect of the life department and Rs. 3,196.25 in respect of its general department.

facts.text: Appellant's income for 1955-56 assessed on September 29, 1956, revised May 21, 1957; life profit Rs. 1,50,191, general loss Rs. 23,667, total income Rs. 1,26,524, refund Rs. 12,867.58.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants income for the assessment year 1955-56 was assessed on September 29, 1956, and later revised on May 21, 1957, and for the year 1956-57, on January 31, 1957. The assessment order for the year 1955-56 showed a profit of Rs. 1,50,191/- in the life department and a loss of Rs. 23,667/- in the general department and it was thereupon assessed on a total income of Rs. 12,6,524/-.

facts.text: For 1956-57 assessed January 31, 1957; life profit Rs. 1,51,835, general loss Rs. 2,06,083, overall loss, full refund due.

anchor.surface_text: The tax due on this income being less than the tax for which credit had been given as tax previously paid, a sum of Rs. 12,867.58 was found refundable to the appellant. In respect of the assessment year 1956-57, the position was that the life department had made a profit of Rs. 1,51,835/- and the general department had incurred a loss of Rs. 2,06,083/- with the result that in that year the appellant had on the whole incurred a loss and did number have to pay any tax.

facts.text: Assessments made after September 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: These assessment orders were however made after the appointed day, namely, September 1, 1956.

facts.text: Taxes credited were deductions under s.18(3) and amounts added under s.16(2) of Income-tax Act, common case of parties.

anchor.surface_text: It has been the companymon case of the parties that the amounts of tax credited as previously paid as earlier mentioned were the deductions uuder s. 18 3  of the Income-tax Act and the amount added to the dividend under s. 16 2  of that Act.

facts.text: Respondent claimed Rs. 9,622.43 out of 1955-56 refund and Rs. 48,271.56 out of 1956-57 refund.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Corporation claimed to be entitled to a refund of Rs. 9,622.43 out of the amount found refundable for 1955-56 and Rs. 48,271.56 out of the amount refundable for 1956-57 under the provisions of s. 7 of the Act of 1956.

facts.text: Tribunal allowed respondent's claim.

anchor.surface_text: As we have earlier stated the Tribunal allowed this claim of the Corporation.

facts.text: Appellant created life insurance fund under s.10(2) Insurance Act, 1938; various shares and securities appertained to it; not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberreason to doubt that the appellant carried out the provisions of S. 10 2  and created the life insurance fund and it is number in dispute that various shares and securities appertained to the life insurance fund of the, appellants business.

facts.text: Right to refund existed on September 1, 1956, as per court finding.

anchor.surface_text: Now as to the first part of this question it seems to us plain that the right to the refund existed on September 1, 1956.

facts.text: Right to refund appertained to life insurance business, court finding.

anchor.surface_text: We turn number to the other part of the question, namely, whether the right to the refund was one appertaining to the life insurance business.

facts.text: Appellant is an insurer within the meaning of the Insurance Act, not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute 1 that the appellant in an insurer within the meaning of the Aci.

facts.text: For 1956-57, refund Rs. 51,468.81 distributed: appellant Rs. 3,196.56, respondent Rs. 48,271.25.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the refund of Rs. 51,468.81 for the year 195657 has to be distributed as follows The appellant, will get Rs. 3,196.56 and the respondent Corporation Rs. 48,271.25.

facts.text: For 1955-56, refund Rs. 12,867.68; general department gets Rs. 3,245.25, balance to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1955-56 however the refund amounted to Rs. 12,867.68 while the amount of tax deducted from the income of the life insurance department or treated as paid from that income was Rs. 48,271.56 and that deducted or treated as paid from the income of the general department was Rs. 3,245.25.

facts.text: Amount of refund already paid by Government; appellant paid its share; respondent paid balance on October 15, 1959 per court order September 21, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: We may add that in certain proceedings, to the details of which it is number necessary to refer, the amount of the refund has already been paid by the Government and out of that sum, the appellant has been paid what we have held it to be entitled to. We declare that the respondent Corporation is entitled to the balance which has already been paid to it on October 15, 1959, by respondent No.2 in companypliance with the order of this Court dated September 21, 1959.
Appeal by Special leave from the order dated August 3, 1959, of the Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur, in case No. 24/XII of 1959.

and under s. 7 of the Act the terms of which we will have to set out later, all rights appertaining to the life insurance business of an insurer, which in the Act is called the controlled business, because vested in the respondent Corporation on the appointed day, that is, September 1, 1956.

concepts.interpretation: Section 7 vests in the Corporation all assets and liabilities appertaining to controlled business (life insurance), including rights existing on appointed day related to that business, such as right to tax refund on life insurance income.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: the account of the life insurance business to be shown separately after deducting the income- tax payable thereon. A numbere to the form states that

concepts.unlisted_description: Transfer and vesting of assets/liabilities of life insurance business

anchor.surface_text: under the provisions of s. 7 of the Act of 1956. As we have earlier stated the Tribunal allowed this claim of the Corporation. Now, s. 7 is in these terms S. 7.  1  On the appointed day there shall be transferred to and vested in the Corporation all the assets and liabilities appertaining to the controlled business of all insurers. The assets appertaining to the controlled business of an insurer shall be deemed to include all rights and powers, and all property, whether movable or immovable, appertaining to his controlled business, including, in particular, cash balances, reserve funds, investments, deposits and all other interests and rights in or arising out of such property as may be in the possession of the insurer and all books of account or documents relating to the controlled business of the insurer land liabilities shall be deemed to include all debts, liabilities and obligations of whatever kind then existing and appertaining to the controlled business of the insurer. x x x x x x x x x x x x

Section 16 2  states that for the purpose of inclusion in the total income of an assessee, dividend paid to him shall be increased to such amount as would, if income-tax at the rate applicable to the total income of the company were deducted therefrom, be equal to the amount of the dividend.

concepts.interpretation: Amount by which dividend increased is treated as tax paid on behalf of shareholder for refund purposes.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: peal. Section 16 2  states that for the purpose of inclusion in the total income of an assessee, dividend paid to him shall be increased to such amoun

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  3  of s. 18 requires that out of the income chargeable as interest on securities income- tax has to be deducted at the source at the maximum rate.

concepts.interpretation: Deduction of tax at source from interest on securities.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  5  states that any deduction made in accordance with the provisions of this section and any sum by which a dividend has been increased under sub.s.  2  of s., 16 shall be treated as a payment of income-tax or super tax on behalf of the person from whose income the deduction was made or of the shareholder, as the case may, be.

concepts.interpretation: Such deductions treated as tax payments for credit/refund.

anchor.surface_text: Section 49, B provides where any dividend has been paid or deemed to have been paid to an assessee who is a shareholder of a company which is assessed to income-tax such assessee shall if the dividend is included in his total income be deemed to have paid himself in respect of such dividend income-tax of an amount by which the dividend has been increased under s. 16 2 .

concepts.unlisted_description: Deeming shareholder to have paid tax on grossed dividend

anchor.surface_text: Section 48 is in these terms If any company satisfies the Income tax Officer that the. amount of tax paid by him or treated as paid on his behalf for any year. exceeds the amount with which he is properly chargeable he shall be entitled to refund of any such excess.

concepts.interpretation: Entitlement to refund where tax paid/deemed exceeds liability.

anchor.surface_text: It is well established that under the Income-tax law the liability to be charged to tax, if any, exists all along. The amount of liability depends on the Finance Act of the year concerned. That is the effect of s.3 of the Income-tax Act which says that the tax at the rates mentioned in the Finance Act shall be charged for the year specified in that Act.

concepts.interpretation: Tax liability arises from the beginning of the assessment year per Finance Act rates; assessment merely quantifies it.

anchor.surface_text: Now a reference has to be made to s. 10 of the Insurance Act, 1938. Under sub-s.  2  of this section an insurer carrying on business of life insurance has to carry to a separate fund, called the life insurance fund, all receipts due in respect of that business and the assets of this fund have to be kept distinct and separate from all his other assets.

concepts.interpretation: Requires separate life insurance fund with distinct assets.

anchor.surface_text: Subsection  3  provides that the life insurance fund shall not be applied directly or indirectly for any purposes other than those of the life insurance business the insurer,.

concepts.unlisted_description: Restriction on use of life fund

anchor.surface_text: Subsection  1  of s. 10 of the Act requires an insurer like the appellant to keep a separate account of all receipts and payments in respect of each separate class of insurance business carried on by him.

concepts.unlisted_description: Separate accounts for classes of business

anchor.surface_text: Section 11 provides that an insurer like the appellant shall keep  a  a balance sheet in accordance with the third Schedule to the Act and  b  a revenue account in accordance with the third Schedule in respect of each class of insurance business carried on by him.

concepts.unlisted_description: Balance sheet and revenue account requirements

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 of the Act requires every insurer carrying on life insurance business to make an actuarial valuation every three years and to submit a report in accordance with the fourth Schedule.

The deduction amounted to payment of tax before assessment and was, therefore, really in the nature of a provisional payment. It was provisional in the sense that to the extent it was on final assessment later, found to be in excess of the tax due, it would cease to be payment of tax and become refundable.

concepts.interpretation: Pre-assessment tax deductions are provisional; excess remains asset if refundable.

concepts.unlisted_description: Nature of tax deducted at source before assessment

anchor.surface_text: Under sub-s.  2  of this section an insurer carrying on business of life insurance has to carry to a separate fund, called the life insurance fund, all receipts due in respect of that business and the assets of this fund have to be kept distinct and separate from all his other assets.

concepts.interpretation: Separate fund for life insurance receipts and assets, distinct from general assets.
concepts.unlisted_description: Statutory definition under Insurance Act s.10(2)

anchor.surface_text: all rights appertaining to the life insurance business of an insurer, which in the Act is called the controlled business, because vested in the respondent Corporation on the appointed day, that is, September 1, 1956.

holdings.text: the right to the refund existed on September 1, 1956

anchor.surface_text: Now as to the first part of this question it seems to us plain that the right to the refund existed on September 1, 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under Income-tax law, tax liability exists from the beginning of the assessment year per s.3 and Finance Act rates; assessment merely quantifies it; refund right arises when excess payment ascertainable, existed before appointed day.

holdings.text: the right to the refund was one appertaining to the life insurance business

anchor.surface_text: We turn now to the other part of the question, namely, whether the right to the refund was one appertaining to the life insurance business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Insurance Act requires separate accounts, funds, balance sheets for life insurance business; income from its assets (shares/securities) appertains to it; tax deductions therefrom provisional, excess refund right retains character appertaining to life business; s.7 LIC Act transfers such rights.

holdings.text: s. 7 of the Act of 1956 operated to transfer this right from it to the respondent Corporation on September 1, 1956
holdings.reasoning_summary: Since refund right appertains to controlled (life) business, explicitly vests in Corporation per s.7(1) including all rights appertaining thereto.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full refund due as overall loss; apportion per departmental tax credits: general department (appellant) retains its share, life (vested in LIC) to respondent.

holdings.text: The entire amount of Rs.3,245.25 should be refunded to [general department/appellant]. The balance ... appertaining [to life] be made over to the respondent Corporation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partial refund; general dept loss means no tax from its assets; its credit fully refunded to appellant; balance from life dept income to respondent; agrees with Tribunal.

holdings.text: This would put the tax liability for the year 1955-56 entirely on the life department

anchor.surface_text: the view taken by the Tribunal and with life insurance in respect of to it, should This is it we agree. This would put the tax liability for the year 1955-56 entirely on the life department

holdings.reasoning_summary: Life dept profitable, general loss-making; liability appertains to profitable dept alone.

holdings.text: the respondent Corporation is entitled to the balance which has already been paid to it

We declare that the respondent Corporation is entitled to the balance which has already been paid to it on October 15, 1959, by respondent No.2 in compliance with the order of this Court dated September 21, 1959.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Remedial declaration confirming prior payments consistent with holdings on entitlements.

precedents.citation: Messrs Chatturam Horilran Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: So it was said in Messrs Chatturam Horilran Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa 1 . The Income-tax Act is a standing piece of legislation which provides the entire machinery for the levy of income-tax. The Finance Act

precedents.case_name: Messrs Chatturam Horilran Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: The Income-tax Act is a standing piece of legislation which provides the entire machinery for the levy of income-tax. The Finance Act of each year imposes the obligation for the payment of a determinate sum for each such year calculated with reference to that machinery.
precedents.cited_holding: The Income-tax Act is a standing piece of legislation which provides the entire machinery for the levy of income-tax. The Finance Act of each year imposes the obligation for the payment of a determinate sum for each such year calculated with reference to that machinery.

anchor.surface_text: We declare that the respondent Corporation is entitled to the balance which has already been paid to it on October 15, 1959, by respondent No.2 in compliance with the order of this Court dated September 21, 1959.

outcome.relief_summary: Court upheld Tribunal's decision that portions of income-tax refunds appertaining to life insurance business vested in respondent Corporation; appellant entitled only to general business portion.
